facts.text: Respondents' ancestors were granted a cash allowance called Tainat by the Peshwas.

facts.text: Treaty of Gulgallee with Jamkhandi dated 6-6-1819 by Mr. Elphinston, Governor of Bombay on behalf of East India Company.

facts.text: One term of the treaty granted continuation of allowances held from Peshwa Government to Gopalrao Jamkhandikar.

facts.text: Allowance to respondents' ancestors was one such allowance continued, with no complaints to reach Government.

anchor.surface_text: It stated that he was to companytinue all allowances and numbercomplaints on. this head were to be suffered to reach the Government  East India Company . The allowance to respondents ancestors was one- such allowance.

facts.text: Allowance amounted to Rs. 2010/- minus Rs. 240/- companymutation amount as per Petha Khata Wahi Extract of 1942-43.

facts.text: The grant was permanent as per the extract.

facts.text: In 1944, the then ruler of Jamkhandi converted the allowance to one for life.

facts.text: Assistant Commissioner granted sum which respondent was receiving.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Mysore Revenue Appellate Tribunal after area became part of Mysore State.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then filed an appeal to the Mysore Revenue Appellate Tribunal as by that time the area had become part of the Mysore State.

facts.text: Tribunal dismissed the appeal, holding ruler had power to change to life allowance.

facts.text: Respondent filed Writ Petition No. 777 of 1961 before Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereupon filed a writ peytition No. 777 before the High Court of Mysore.

facts.text: Mysore High Court directed payment of Rs.14,070 (7 times Rs.2010) assuming grant hereditary.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court ... directed that a sum of Rs. 14,070 being seven times annual cash allowance of Rs. 29010 be paid to the respondent on ,the basis that the.grant was hereditary.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal is allowed and the judgment and order of the High Court of Mysore set aside.

facts.text: Ruler of Jamkhandi in 1944 had sovereign power to convert permanent allowance to life allowance.

arguments.claim: Ruler enjoyed uncontrolled sovereign powers prior to integration and could modify grants like firmans at will

anchor.surface_text: In Ameer-un-Nissa Begum v. Mahboob Begum  AIR 1953 SC 352  this Court stated the companystitutional position of the Nizani of Hyderabad in these words It cannot be dispute that prior to the integration of Hyderabad State with the Indian Union and the companying into force of the Indian Constitution,the Nizam of Hyderabad enjoyed uncontrolled sovereign powers. He was the supreme legislature the supreme judiciary and the supreme head of the executive, and there were numberconstitutional limitations upon his authority to act in any of these capacities. The Firmans were expressions of the sovereign will of the Nizam anti they Were,binding in the same way any other law- nay, they would override all other laws which were in companyflict with them. So long as a particular Fireman, hdld the field that alone would govern or regulate the rights of the parties companycerned, though it companyld be annulled or modi-fied by a later Firman at any time that the Nizam willed. ... It follows therefore that if the ruler of Jamkhandi had changed the permanent cash allowance granted to the respondents ancestors to one for life it is legally valid and it cannot be questioned.

arguments.claim: Rs. 240 commutation amount must be deducted from cash allowance for compensation as it is service allowance

anchor.surface_text: The Mysore High Court was, therefore, wrong in holding that this sum of Rs. 240 cannot be deducted from the cash allowance while calculating the companypensation payable to the respondent. ... As already mentioned the Petha Khata Wahi extract shows the allowance at Rs. 2010.00 minus Rs. 240.00 being the companymutation amount. These allowances being service allowances, the deduction is for the payment to the person who was doing the service in place of the cash allowance holder.

arguments.claim: Bombay Merged Territories Miscellaneous Alienations Abolition Act 1955 violates Art. 19(1)(f) or Art. 31(2) like the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Cash Grants Act

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Datar appearing for the respondent companytended that as this Court in M.P. State v. Ranojirao  1968 3 SCR 489  has held that the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Cash Grants Act violates Art. 19 1  f  or Art. 31 2  of the Constitution, and so struck it down, the Bombay Merged Territories Miscellaneous Alienation Abolition Act is also liable to be struck down on the same ground.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court declines to express opinion, leaves liberty to move High Court

holdings.text: The ruler of Jamkhandi had sovereign power in 1944 to change the permanent cash allowance granted to the respondents' ancestors to one for life and such change is legally valid and cannot be questioned.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that if the ruler of Jamkhandi had changed the permanent cash allowance granted to the respondents ancestors to one for life it is legally valid and it cannot be questioned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied precedent from Ameer-un-Nissa Begum on uncontrolled sovereign powers of princely rulers pre-integration, allowing modification of grants like firmans at will; position applies to Jamkhandi ruler.

holdings.text: The sum of Rs. 240 being the commutation amount must be deducted from the cash allowance of Rs. 2010 while calculating the compensation payable to the respondent as it represents service allowance deduction.

anchor.surface_text: The Mysore High Court was, therefore, wrong in holding that this sum of Rs. 240 cannot be deducted from the cash allowance while calculating the companypensation payable to the respondent. ... As already mentioned the Petha Khata Wahi extract shows the allowance at Rs. 2010.00 minus Rs. 240.00 being the companymutation amount.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petha Khata Wahi extract explicitly shows Rs. 2010 minus Rs. 240 as commutation for service; consistent with actual payments made; High Court erred in ignoring this.

holdings.text: The decision of the Mysore Revenue Appellate Tribunal is right.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Mysore Revenue Appellate Tribunal is, therefore, right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal correctly recognized sovereign powers of ruler allowing change to life allowance and dismissed appeal accordingly.

holdings.text: The judgment and order of the Mysore High Court is wrong and set aside.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that clearly the decision of the Mysore High Court is wrong.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court failed to address ruler's power to convert grant and wrongly assumed hereditary nature entitling to seven times compensation.

holdings.text: This appeal is allowed and the judgment and order of the High Court of Mysore set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal is allowed and the judgment and order of the High Court of Mysore set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on holdings that ruler's modification valid and deduction required, restoring Tribunal's order for three times net life allowance.

precedents.cited_proposition: Prior to integration, rulers of princely states like the Nizam of Hyderabad enjoyed uncontrolled sovereign powers as supreme legislature, judiciary, and executive with no constitutional limitations; firmans expressed sovereign will, binding and override other laws, modifiable by later firman at will
precedents.cited_holding: The Nizam of Hyderabad enjoyed uncontrolled sovereign powers... A rigid line of demarcation... would... be not justified or even possible.
